Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the residence requirement for Canadian citizenship under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessment: Respondent's absence from Canada for approximately three and a half years during the four-year period preceding application
Decision_Outcome: Minister's appeal allowed; Citizenship Court's decision set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate compliance with residency requirement
Credibility_Factor: Citizenship Judge relied on family connections rather than applicantâ€™s personal connection to Canada
Legal_Rule: Permanent resident must accumulate at least three years of residence in Canada within four years before application
Procedural_Issue: Remand for reconsideration due to flawed assessment
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet statutory residency requirement
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicant did not meet residency requirement
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision found unreasonable due to reliance on irrelevant factors
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and pattern of absences from Canada, family ties
Applicant_Challenge: Demonstrating sufficient physical presence in Canada
Court_Result: Case referred back for reconsideration by another Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Type: Residency records, travel history, family connection evidence
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of original decision and referral for new hearing
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by administrative rehearing
Applicable_Process: Citizenship application review and judicial appeal process
Governing_Rule: Residence requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
